title: Amount of DNA in Cell Cycle

content.description: The relative amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a cell at various stages of the cell cycle is shown in Figure 1 .
content.question: Figure 1. Amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></math> per cell during different stages of the cell cycle, relative to the beginning of the <math alttext="G 1" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>G</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> stage Which of the following best describes how the amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the cell changes during <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> phase?

choices.label: The amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> doubles as the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is replicated.
The amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> slightly increases as a result of new organelle synthesis.
The amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> does not change while the cell grows.
The amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is halved as the cell divides into two daughter cells.

content.answer: The amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is halved as the cell divides into two daughter cells.
